> 
> "Each application defines goals for the underlying system, against
> which the system's performance can be measured."
> 
> The goal of the underlying system, as defined by the "post a comment"
> application, is "accept a comment" and the system's performance in
> this regard may be easily measured...
>

Actually, my example showed how to measure the performance of the
underlying origin server component, which is a useful component topology
to measure.  The performance of a larger set of the underlying component
topology could be measured at the user agent, from the intiation of the
POST request until the next steady-state is achieved, i.e. whatever the
user agent does with the 201 response, like proceed to reload and render
the comment thread.

That way, the "in-circuit" component topology would include everything
that affects the user-perceived performance of a REST application being
executed within, say, a Web browser.  The goal of the underlying system
in this case, would be "post a comment and proceed to the next steady-
state", every time it executes the "post a comment" application (still
assuming the 201 case).

-Eric
